item.title: Datadesk: What is it?
item.description:
The worst document format that exists, and why i made it.

But tell me: What the fuck is it?

Datadesk (DS) is an interpreted markup language that bridges the gap between images and text files. Characters and sentences are placed by the user on a matrix.

DS has 4 main commands:

  1. /s - writes a sentence to the screen, automatically placing multiple lines until the end of the command (/e).
  2. /r - draws a rectangle on the screen.
  3. /e - ends the /s command (and every command that has a dynamic argument number).
  4. / - used only once, “/” means the scene root in a datadesk source file.

There is also a line numbering argument for /s evoked by the letter “L” like this: /sL

The language uses a pass-based syntax in which the return key separates different passes. This approach makes writing software with datadesk in mind really easy. It works like this:

  • 1st pass: the y coordinate
  • 2nd pass: the x coordinate
  • 3rd pass: the command / a character

If the 3rd pass is a command there are arguments after the pass; Technically these are called “Optional passes”. The y coordinate is specified first because ncurses works the same way. Even if it feels weird at first, it is really simple in the long run. This decision makes sense because people first specify the row (y), and then the column (x).

The DRAWER interpreter.

DRAWER (DRAWER Reference Alpha-stage Working without Errors and it’s Robust as fuck) interpreter, is a ncurses based DS interpreter made by me from scratch. Currently it only has around 200 lines of code and it’s extremely minimal. You can use DRAWER with the following command.

drawer <path to the ds source file.ds>

The document is shown after the execution of that command, you can close the interpreter with F12. drawer -h shows you the version of drawer and cli arguments that you can use with it. drawer -d shows you a datadesk demo file containing some nice art, graphics etc.

Datadesk: The sequel (what will follow DS1?)

I’m currently planning on adding support on multiple pages in the same document and adding variables. Maybe i will do things such as block quotes and support for slanted and bold text.

DS3 will probably have some interactive elements added as well.

What happened to your previous project, allcom?

I lost motivation and cancelled the game. That’s it.

item.title: Linux is dead (and we killed it)
item.description:
Look, it’s just my opinion. But Linux is truly dead. It has become unstable, bloated and unusable. Even Windows beats most popular distros in that regard.

Even “pro” distributions like Arch or Gentoo suffer from most of the problems that modern UNIX has. An example that i like to use is NetworkManager, a truly useless piece of software. This deamon really is just a workaround that makes systemd’s network system usable to your average Joe.

Other init-systems like openrc and runit just work. Yes - they require a dhcp service (if you even use dhcp) - but even then these init systems ship with at least working network setup tools.

But let’s analyze the downfall of Linux in detail

The Desktop

For me it all started with GNOME 3. I know I sound stupid because everyone bullies GNOME and systemd, but hear me out.

GNOME 2 was perfect. Ok, maybe not. Still it was really close to perfection. Why? It was easy to use, stable and customizable - everything you want from a desktop.

But then, from nowhere - gnome 3 appeared. They have scrapped everything they built since the 90s and started from scratch. And it wasn’t a success, actually, it was the Windows Vista of linux.

If someone came to my house with a gun and said “describe what gnome 3 in 2011 was in 5 seconds or i’ll shoot you” i would say that it was janky, very janky. I didn’t understand why the dev-team did this, and i don’t understand it now. After some time the GNOME team fixed their desktop, and it was actually pretty easy to use. Most popular distributions like ubuntu returned to their roots with shipping gnome again. But while all of this was happening, gnome 3 was the literal definition of a “dumpster fire” under the hood. Through time the team added too many unneceseary features to gnome and added systemd dependencies. Because of the popularity of systemd, no one saw this as a problem. But it really is. Now with GNOME 42 using 2 gigs idling i can confortably say that it won’t ever go back to it’s days of glory.

KDE had gone a simillar route, but with a happier ending overall. KDE 3 was the best alternative to GNOME 2, and the most customizable desktop of it’s time. In 2008 / 2009 KDE 4 was released. And you guessed it - it was a total disaster. Everybody hated this thing, it was barely usable. At least GNOME 3 didn’t crashed almost every time you wanted to change a theme. The succesor to KDE 4, Plasma is actually very successful to this day. It mostly reclaimed the desktop throne from KDE 3 / Trinity, and it is the favourite to this day. But it didn’t protect KDE from it’s jank.

KDE Plasma jank list

  1. a ton of confusing menus
  2. QT5 is still a mess
  3. Uses even more ram than GNOME
  4. Outdated widgets
  5. Feature Creep
  6. Weird Design Choices
  7. A shitty store app
  8. Broken, unfinished app suite
  9. Breeze theme is the only one that is actually usable and integrates with GTK
  10. Unpolished, buggy animations
  11. Bugs
  12. Bugs!
  13. Even More Bugs!

Ok, let’s end it here.

systemd

From the other side of our linux coin is systemd, a linux init system that creeped into every distro since Debian 7 codenamed “Jessie” Most people just don’t care enough about linux’s internal workings to hate systemd - it is still a usable and easy to use init system. I know that it’s a meme, but systemd really is the most bloated PID1 that ever existed, having a ton of useless services that shouldn’t even be there.

The not-so comprehensive list of useless soystemd wonk and jank

  1. systemd-homed
  2. systemd-logind
  3. systemd-boot
  4. systemd/Journal (yes, there are multiple naming conventions used there)
  5. systemd-sysusers
  6. systemd-nspawn
  7. systemd-stub
  8. systemd.mount (another naming convention)
  9. systemd-fstab-generator (WHY, JUST WHY. genfstab exists.)

all of these systemd modules shouldn’t be a part of the init system, but they somehow are…

Aside from systemd’s disregard of the UNIX philosophy, it boots significantly slower than for example runit or s6 (at least on all of my machines). It is really a beast, a performance hog and it simply just does too much. PID 1 should just start some services with dependency management and that’s it. Another big thing that i hate is pulseaudio, even if it is being currently replaced by pipewire (and that’s really good) - it is a wonky mess that never works, uses too much system resources, isn’t system-wide, has horrible command-line interfaces and is just simply buggy. We should stick to alsa in the long-term. Why? It simply just works, yes - only after extensive configuration to let it work on modern browsers, add multi-channel support etc. - but it works.

The mentality of Lennart Poettering’s software is spreading too.

What is Freedom anyway?

Freedom in linux is decaying. Most people are forced to use pulseaudio (because of steam and other stuff), X.Org (wayland exists, but it isn’t as stable), systemd (because gnome) and other things. In the early days of linux there really was more choice than now. In the 90s and early 2000s, when UNIX systems came to your average Joe, people used BSDs, Linuxes, BeOS etc. Now it’s just ubuntu and arch.

People started realizing this and now some are moving to BSD or - if someone doesn’t care about privacy - MacOS. I suspect that in a few years most popular linux distros will be closer to windows than to any free-software UNIX imaginable. But let’s end this for now.

Conclusion

Linux users wanting it to be more “user-friendly” killed linux. Yes, it is more integrated - but at what cost? GNOME 3 and systemd are the greatest examples of this trend.

item.title: Piracy is 80% morally correct
item.description:
“this will be a controversial one”

Is Piracy Stealing?

No, not at all. Unlike real piracy (a group of guys goes into a boat in the middle of the fucking ocean and steals everything) nothing just ceases to exist. So technically it is just unauthorized file copying, which sounds stupid because everyone can copy files on their disk in any capacity.

Even then, let’s be honest. Stealing (like real stealing) from big corporations doesn’t hurt them much + nobody cares about them (outside of the apple community where apple inc. is their lord and savior).

What about that 20%?

That 20% is mostly stuff that is already illegal, or it’s just immoral anyways.

  • Porn (don’t coom kids.)

  • Child Po- Cheese Pizza

(Why would you download this, yes downloading this stuff from torrent with a VPN is safe (kind of) but why?)

  • Some indie games made by a guy in his basement worth for five bucks (not talking about AAA’s)

(Like these people actually want to make something good, support them. But still “no tux, no bux” is a rule that i’ll follow.)

The BitTorrent protocol itself

I like torrents mostly because the BitTorrent protocol revolutionized the Internet. It was created when your average internet connection was around 50 KB/s, and most people still used dial-up. But why it was so revolutional?

First, it is very hard to shut down a torrent network - that’s why it is so commonly used for piracy and rare / lost media archival. Back in the day most websites were owned by people, not companies. A side effect of this was that servers of a website could be shut down at any time due to many reasons. The creator of that site could be bored, forgot to turn on his server etc. Obviously, when the servers are down, you cannot download stuff from this person. BitTorrent is decentralized, so everyone having the file on his own computer is a potential server. Only one person online (more popular torrents have even 50 people at the same time) can keep the torrent up and send the data to you. Because of this decentralization, most companies can’t stop even a single torrent.

Aside from that, download speeds of the files sent through torrent weren’t capped by the server, so these files could be downloaded with very high speeds. These reasons are all i need to prefer torrent over anything else.

how 2 interwebz pirate

First, you need to know what is a torrent tracker. A torrent tracker is a server that - as the name suggests - tracks peers across many torrent networks. Most of these trackers are aggregated and hosted on sites like:

  • thepiratebay.org
  • 1337x.to
  • rutracker.org (it’s in russian, some basic language skills required to use it on a daily basis)

these are sites that i prefer to use.

How to download files from them? It’s easy.

  1. go to the website (example is from thepiratebay.org)
  2. search what you want
  3. click on it (and avoid ads when possible)
  4. click on the button with da magnet

your client should appear and set up the torrent for you by now.

  1. relax and wait till the thing completes.
  2. now you have your favourite music album, hentai game, or something else on your hard drive!

Ending

So that was it, i hope this guide to torrents was useful.

item.title: Reserve
item.description:
What the fuck is it?

m4kulatura’s private reserve (MPR) is a repository full of software, games, music and other stuff. it is submitted by m4kulatura and his friends mostly for personal use and archival. still, anyone with an internet connection can download files from the repo.

download as much as you want!

http server: https://ftp.whentheh.tk

(currently inactive due to maintenance)
